name: Pull-up Training
description: A structured pull-up progression workout. Focus on quality movement over speed.

exercises.name: Dead Hang
exercises.description: Hang from the bar with shoulders relaxed (not actively engaging). Focus on your grip and controlled breathing. Let gravity decompress your spine.
exercises.tip: Breathe slowly and let your shoulders relax completely.

exercises.name: Scapular Pulls
exercises.description: Hang from the bar with arms straight. Depress and retract your shoulder blades (squeeze them down and together) WITHOUT bending your elbows. Slow and controlled — this is mobility work.

exercises.name: Easy Assisted Pull-ups
exercises.description: Use a thick resistance band for plenty of assistance. Focus on full range of motion — dead hang at the bottom, chin over bar at the top. These should feel comfortable.

exercises.name: Harder Assisted Pull-ups
exercises.description: Switch to a thinner band (less assistance). Same movement as warmup — dead hang to chin over bar. Push yourself on these! Rest fully between sets.

exercises.name: Top Hold
exercises.description: Jump or step up to chin-over-bar position and hold. Keep shoulders down and back. Maintain tension throughout — don't let yourself slowly sink.

exercises.name: Band Curls
exercises.description: Stand on the resistance band, palms facing up, curl both arms to shoulder height. Slow and controlled — 2 seconds up, 2 seconds down.
exercises.tip: These support elbow health for pull-up training.

name: Push & Core
description: The natural complement to pull-up training. Push movements balance the pulling muscles, and core work builds the stability you need for strict pull-ups.

exercises.name: Arm Circles
exercises.description: Stand tall, extend arms to the sides. Make large slow circles, 10 forward then 10 backward. Gradually increase the circle size.

exercises.name: Wall Slides
exercises.description: Stand with back flat against a wall, arms raised to 90° (goalpost position). Slowly slide arms overhead while keeping elbows and wrists touching the wall. Return slowly.
exercises.tip: If your lower back arches away from the wall, that's tight lats — common if you train pull-ups. This drill also fixes that.

exercises.name: Push-ups
exercises.description: Hands shoulder-width apart, body in a straight line from head to heels. Lower chest to the floor, then press back up. Scale by doing them from your knees if needed.

exercises.name: Pike Push-ups
exercises.description: Start in a downward-dog position with hips high. Bend elbows to lower the top of your head toward the floor, then press back up. This targets the shoulders — the push equivalent of pull-ups.

exercises.name: Tricep Dips
exercises.description: Use a sturdy chair or bench behind you. Grip the edge, legs extended, lower yourself by bending elbows to 90°, then press back up. Keep elbows pointing straight back, not flaring out.

exercises.name: Plank
exercises.description: Forearms on the floor, elbows under shoulders. Body in a straight line — squeeze glutes, brace your core, don't let hips sag or pike up. Breathe steadily.
exercises.tip: Think of it as a full-body squeeze, not just holding your abs tight.

exercises.name: Hollow Body Hold
exercises.description: Lie on your back. Press your lower back firmly into the floor. Raise your arms overhead and legs to about 45°. Hold this 'banana' shape. If it's too hard, bend your knees.
exercises.tip: This is one of the best exercises for pull-ups — it trains the exact body tension you need.
